docs.title: Starship HUD
docs.text: Starship HUD is an immersive, diegetic spaceship interface designed for tabletop RPG campaigns. It transforms your ship into a living character with real-time status displays, alerts, and interactive controls.

docs.title: What is Starship HUD?
docs.text:
Starship HUD provides a web-based "bridge console" experience for your tabletop game:

  • Players see their ship's systems, alerts, and tasks through station-specific panels
  • GMs control the narrative through scenarios, incidents, and system state changes
  • The ship becomes a character with moods, damage states, and evolving conditions

docs.title: For Players
docs.text:
• Station Panels - Each crew role (Engineering, Helm, Operations, etc.) gets a dedicated console view
  • Real-time Status - See system health, alerts, and incoming transmissions as they happen
  • Task Queue - Claim and complete tasks to address ship problems
  • Contact Tracking - Monitor nearby vessels with threat indicators and dossiers

docs.title: For GMs
docs.text:
• Panel Builder - Design custom panels with drag-and-drop widget placement
  • Scenario System - Pre-script narrative beats with timed status changes and spawned tasks
  • Direct Control - Manually adjust any system state, send transmissions, or create incidents
  • Rehearsal Mode - Test scenarios before running them live

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Install Starship HUD using Docker
  2. Complete first-run setup with the demo ship
  3. Learn about panels and how to customize them
  4. Explore widgets to understand what's available

docs.title: Design Philosophy
docs.text:
Starship HUD is built around the idea that your ship's interface should feel diegetic - like a real piece of in-universe technology, not a generic web dashboard.

  • Status changes have visual weight (color, motion, glows)
  • The interface uses a consistent sci-fi visual language
  • Information density is high but readable
  • Panels never scroll - they're designed like physical instrument displays

docs.title: First Run
docs.text: After installing Starship HUD, here's how to get oriented and start using it.

docs.title: Accessing the HUD
docs.text:
Starship HUD has two main interfaces:

URL Purpose http://your-server:8000 Player View - Station panels and the main HUD http://your-server:8000/admin Admin Panel - GM controls and configuration

docs.title: The Demo Ship
docs.text:
On first run, Starship HUD creates a demo ship called "ISS Horizon" with:

  • Pre-configured system states (reactor, life support, engines, etc.)
  • Sample panels for different stations
  • Example contacts and transmissions
  • Demonstration scenarios

This gives you a working example to explore before building your own ship.

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
The player view shows panels organized by station. Use the navigator (typically in a corner) to switch between available panels:

  • Bridge - Command overview and posture controls
  • Engineering - Reactor, power, and system health
  • Operations - Sensors, communications, and contacts
  • Helm - Navigation and maneuvering

docs.title: Reading the Interface
docs.text:
Panels display ship status through widgets. Key things to notice:

  • Colors indicate status - Green is good, yellow needs attention, red is critical
  • Icons provide redundancy - Status is never communicated by color alone
  • Motion has meaning - Flickering or pulsing indicates degraded/critical states

docs.title: Interacting
docs.text:
Some widgets are interactive:

  • Task Queue - Claim tasks assigned to your station, mark them complete
  • Posture Display - Change ship threat posture (if permitted)
  • Contact Tracker - Pin contacts, expand dossiers

docs.title: Admin Panel Walkthrough
docs.text: Access the admin panel at /admin. You'll need to enter your ADMIN_TOKEN.

docs.title: Dashboard
docs.text:
The admin dashboard shows:

  • Ship overview with all system states
  • Active incidents and tasks
  • Quick actions for common operations

docs.title: Key Admin Sections
docs.text:
Panels - View and edit panel layouts

  • Add, remove, and resize widgets
  • Configure widget bindings to system states
  • Preview how panels look at different sizes

System States - Direct control of ship systems

  • Change status (operational → degraded → critical, etc.)
  • Adjust numeric values
  • Apply glitch effects

Scenarios - Pre-scripted narrative sequences

  • Create scenarios with timed actions
  • Test with rehearsal mode
  • Run live during sessions

Transmissions - Send messages to players

  • Queue transmissions for dramatic timing
  • Mark as read/unread

Contacts - Manage sensor contacts

  • Create ships, stations, and anomalies
  • Set threat levels and affiliations
  • Add dossier information

docs.title: Verification Checklist
docs.text:
After setup, verify everything works:

  • [ ] Homepage loads at /
  • [ ] Panel index shows available stations
  • [ ] At least one panel displays widgets correctly
  • [ ] Admin dashboard is accessible at /admin
  • [ ] System states update when modified in admin
  • [ ] Data persists after container restart

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
1. Learn about panels - Understand how to design your own station layouts
  2. Explore widgets - See all available widget types
  3. Set up scenarios - Create narrative sequences for your sessions

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Starship HUD is deployed using Docker. This guide covers setup on Unraid and general Docker environments.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Docker and Docker Compose installed
  • A machine accessible to your players (local network or internet)

docs.title: Quick Start with Docker Compose
docs.text:
1. Create a directory for the app:

    mkdir -p starship-hud
cd starship-hud

  2. Download the docker-compose.yml:

    curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/your-repo/starship-hud/main/docker-compose.yml

  3. Create an environment file:

    echo "ADMIN_TOKEN=$(openssl rand -hex 16)" > .env

    Save your admin token

    The ADMIN_TOKEN is your password for the admin panel. Save it somewhere secure.

  4. Start the container:

    docker compose up -d

  5. Access the HUD at http://your-server-ip:8000

docs.title: Using Docker Compose (Recommended)
docs.text:
1. SSH into your Unraid server or use the terminal

  2. Create a directory for the app:

    mkdir -p /mnt/user/appdata/starship-hud
cd /mnt/user/appdata/starship-hud

  3. Download the docker-compose.yml:

    curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/your-repo/starship-hud/main/docker-compose.yml

  4. Create environment file:

    echo "ADMIN_TOKEN=$(openssl rand -hex 16)" > .env

  5. Start the container:

    docker compose up -d

  6. Access the HUD at http://your-unraid-ip:8000

docs.title: Using Docker Run
docs.text:
docker run -d \
  --name starship-hud \
  --restart unless-stopped \
  -p 8000:8000 \
  -v /mnt/user/appdata/starship-hud/data:/app/data \
  -e ADMIN_TOKEN=your-secure-token \
  starship-hud:latest

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Description Default PORT Port to expose 8000 ADMIN_TOKEN Admin authentication token dev-admin-token DATABASE_URL SQLite database path sqlite+aiosqlite:///./data/starship.db

docs.title: Persistent Storage
docs.text:
The SQLite database is stored in /app/data inside the container. Mount this to a persistent location to preserve your data across container restarts:

/path/to/your/data:/app/data

docs.title: Docker Compose
docs.text:
cd /path/to/starship-hud
docker compose pull
docker compose up -d

docs.title: Docker Run
docs.text:
docker stop starship-hud
docker rm starship-hud
docker pull starship-hud:latest
# Re-run the docker run command

docs.title: Backup
docs.text:
The database is a single SQLite file. To backup:

cp /path/to/data/starship.db /path/to/backups/starship-hud-$(date +%Y%m%d).db

docs.title: Reverse Proxy (Optional)
docs.text:
If using Nginx Proxy Manager or similar:

  1. Point your domain to the server IP
  2. Configure proxy host:
    • Domain: hud.yourdomain.com
    • Forward Hostname: starship-hud (or server IP)
    • Forward Port: 8000
    • Enable Websockets (for future real-time updates)

docs.title: Container won't start
docs.text:
Check logs:

docker logs starship-hud

docs.title: Database issues
docs.text:
Reset the database (this will delete all data):

docker exec starship-hud rm /app/data/starship.db
docker restart starship-hud

docs.title: Port conflicts
docs.text:
Ensure port 8000 is not in use:

netstat -tulpn | grep 8000

Change the port in your environment file or docker-compose.yml if needed.

docs.title: Panels
docs.text: Panels are the primary interface for players. Each panel represents a station view - a collection of widgets arranged like a physical instrument console.

docs.title: Panels vs Widgets
docs.text:
• Panels define layout and composition - where things go on screen
  • Widgets render data and provide interaction - what's displayed

Think of a panel as a physical console, and widgets as the individual gauges, displays, and controls mounted on it.

docs.title: No-Scroll Design
docs.text: Panels are designed to fit entirely within the viewport, like a real bridge console. They never require scrolling to see all information. This constraint keeps information dense but accessible.

docs.title: Player Navigation
docs.text:
Players navigate between panels using the on-screen navigator. The navigator style varies by configuration but typically appears as:

  • A station selector dial
  • A tabbed console interface
  • A corner menu

docs.title: Panel Index
docs.text:
The main player view (/) shows available panels grouped by station. Players can:

  • See which panels exist for their station
  • Navigate directly to a specific panel
  • View a summary of the ship's overall state

docs.title: Creating Panels (Admin)
docs.text: In the admin panel, navigate to Panels to manage panel layouts.

docs.title: Creating a New Panel
docs.text:
1. Click Add Panel
  2. Enter panel details:
    • Name - Display name (e.g., "Engineering Main")
    • Station - Which crew role sees this panel
    • Description - Optional description
  3. Save to create an empty panel

docs.title: The Grid System
docs.text:
Panels use a 24-column grid with 20px row height. This provides fine-grained control over widget placement.

  • Widgets snap to grid cells
  • Each widget has minimum size requirements
  • The grid ensures consistent spacing

docs.title: Adding Widgets
docs.text:
1. Open a panel in edit mode
  2. Click Add Widget or drag from the widget catalog
  3. Select widget type from the categorized list
  4. Position and resize the widget on the grid
  5. Configure widget settings (bindings, labels, etc.)

docs.title: Widget Bindings
docs.text:
Most widgets need to be "bound" to data sources:

Binding Type Purpose Example system_state_id Single system Health bar showing reactor status system_state_ids Multiple systems Dependencies graph dataset_id Tabular data Data table widget None Self-contained Title, divider, spacer

docs.title: Positioning Tips
docs.text:
• Group related information - Keep status displays near their controls
  • Use visual hierarchy - Important info at eye level (upper portion)
  • Leave breathing room - Don't pack every pixel; spacers help
  • Test at target resolution - Ensure nothing clips or overlaps

docs.title: Station-Specific Design
docs.text:
Design panels for their audience:

  • Bridge - High-level overview, posture controls, alert feed
  • Engineering - Detailed system status, health bars, dependencies
  • Operations - Sensors, contacts, communications
  • Helm - Navigation data, radar, maneuvering status

docs.title: Information Density
docs.text:
Balance density with readability:

  • Use compact widgets for secondary information
  • Reserve larger widgets for critical displays
  • Leverage layout widgets (dividers, spacers) to create visual sections

docs.title: Responsive Considerations
docs.text:
Panels are designed for a target resolution (typically 1920x1080). If players use different screen sizes:

  • Smaller screens may require simplified panels
  • Consider creating variant panels for different display sizes
  • Test on actual player hardware before sessions

docs.title: Engineering Overview
docs.text:
A typical engineering panel might include:

  • Title - "Engineering Station"
  • Health Bars - Reactor, power grid, life support
  • Status Displays - Individual system states
  • System Dependencies - Visual graph of system relationships
  • Task Queue - Engineering-assigned tasks
  • Alert Feed - Recent alerts

docs.title: Tactical Display
docs.text:
A tactical panel might include:

  • Radar - Polar display of sensor contacts
  • Contact Tracker - Detailed contact list
  • Posture Display - Current threat posture
  • Alert Feed - Combat-relevant alerts

docs.title: Widgets Overlap
docs.text:
• Check widget positions in edit mode
  • Ensure no widgets share the same grid cells
  • Resize widgets to fit their content

docs.title: Panel Doesn't Fit Screen
docs.text:
• Panel may be designed for a larger resolution
  • Remove or shrink widgets to fit
  • Consider creating a compact variant

docs.title: Widget Shows "No Data"
docs.text:
• Check widget bindings in edit mode
  • Ensure the bound system state exists
  • Verify the system state has data

docs.title: Scenarios
docs.text: Scenarios are pre-scripted narrative sequences that automate ship state changes during play. They let GMs prepare dramatic moments in advance and execute them with a single click.

docs.title: What Scenarios Do
docs.text:
A scenario is a sequence of actions that happen over time:

  • Change system status (reactor goes critical)
  • Adjust system values (shields drop to 50%)
  • Spawn incidents (hull breach in cargo bay)
  • Create tasks (repair the conduit)
  • Send transmissions (incoming distress call)
  • Emit events (for the ship log)

docs.title: When to Use Scenarios
docs.text:
Scenarios work best for:

  • Planned narrative beats - The ambush you know is coming
  • Complex cascades - Multiple systems failing in sequence
  • Timed events - Things that happen at specific intervals
  • Reusable situations - Common encounters you run often

For improvised moments, use direct admin controls instead.

docs.title: Creating Scenarios (Admin)
docs.text: In the admin panel, navigate to Scenarios to manage your scripted sequences.

docs.title: Basic Structure
docs.text:
A scenario consists of:

  1. Name - Identifier for the scenario
  2. Description - What this scenario represents
  3. Actions - The sequence of things that happen

docs.title: Action Types
docs.text: Action What It Does set_status Change a system's status (operational → critical) adjust_value Change a system's numeric value spawn_incident Create a new incident spawn_task Create a task for a station send_transmission Queue a message to players emit_event Add an entry to the ship log delay Wait before the next action

docs.title: Example: Reactor Overload
docs.text:
A scenario for a reactor emergency might include:

  1. emit_event - "Power fluctuation detected in main reactor"
  2. delay - 5 seconds
  3. set_status - Reactor → degraded
  4. spawn_task - "Stabilize reactor core" (Engineering, 60s timer)
  5. delay - 30 seconds
  6. adjust_value - Reactor power output -20%
  7. set_status - Reactor → compromised
  8. spawn_incident - "Reactor instability" (major severity)

docs.title: Direct Execution
docs.text:
From the Scenarios list:

  1. Find the scenario you want to run
  2. Click Run
  3. Actions execute in sequence

The scenario runs in real-time. Players see status changes, tasks appear, transmissions arrive.

docs.title: Rehearsal Mode
docs.text:
Test scenarios before running them live:

  1. Click Rehearse instead of Run
  2. Scenario executes against a snapshot of current state
  3. See what would happen without affecting the real ship
  4. Exit rehearsal to discard changes

Always Rehearse First

Run new scenarios in rehearsal mode during prep to catch timing issues or unintended effects.

docs.title: Stopping a Scenario
docs.text:
If a scenario is running and you need to stop it:

  1. Go to the active scenarios view
  2. Click Stop on the running scenario
  3. Remaining actions are cancelled

Actions already executed are not rolled back.

docs.title: Incidents and Tasks
docs.text: Scenarios often spawn incidents and tasks. Understanding these systems helps design better scenarios.

docs.title: Incidents
docs.text:
An incident is an ongoing situation affecting the ship:

  • Has a name, description, and severity
  • Can link to affected systems
  • Progresses through states: active → contained → resolved (or failed)

Incident Severities:

Severity Meaning Minor Annoyance, low priority Moderate Needs attention soon Major Significant problem Critical Immediate threat

docs.title: Tasks
docs.text:
A task is work for the crew to complete:

  • Assigned to a specific station
  • Can have time limits
  • Success/failure triggers consequences

Task Flow:

pending → active (claimed) → succeeded/failed/expired

Task Consequences:

Tasks can trigger effects on completion:

  • on_success - What happens if completed successfully
  • on_failure - What happens if failed
  • on_expire - What happens if the timer runs out

Example: A "Seal hull breach" task might:

  • On success: Set hull integrity to operational
  • On failure: Spawn follow-up task, reduce atmosphere
  • On expire: Set hull to critical, spawn evacuation incident

docs.title: Pacing
docs.text:
• Build tension gradually - Start with warnings, escalate to crisis
  • Use delays - Give players time to react between beats
  • Leave room for player agency - Tasks let players affect outcomes

docs.title: Branching
docs.text:
Scenarios are linear, but you can create branching through task consequences:

  • Task success prevents escalation
  • Task failure triggers additional scenario or incident
  • Multiple tasks with different stations create coordination challenges

docs.title: Reusability
docs.text:
Design scenarios for reuse:

  • Keep them focused (one situation per scenario)
  • Use generic system names that match your ship
  • Document expected starting conditions

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
Always test scenarios:

  1. Read through - Do the actions make sense in order?
  2. Rehearse - Run in rehearsal mode to see timing
  3. Adjust - Tweak delays and values based on testing
  4. Document - Note what state the ship should be in before running

docs.title: Combat Encounter
docs.text:
"Hostile Contact Engagement"

  1. emit_event: "Hostile contact on intercept course"
  2. send_transmission: Warning from hostile vessel
  3. delay: 10s
  4. set_status: Shields → degraded
  5. spawn_task: "Reinforce forward shields" (Ops, 30s)
  6. delay: 20s
  7. spawn_incident: "Taking fire" (moderate)
  8. adjust_value: Hull integrity -15%

docs.title: System Failure
docs.text:
"Life Support Cascade"

  1. emit_event: "Anomaly in atmospheric processors"
  2. delay: 5s
  3. set_status: Life support → degraded
  4. spawn_task: "Diagnose life support fault" (Engineering, 45s)
  5. delay: 30s
  6. adjust_value: Atmosphere quality -10%
  7. set_status: Life support → compromised
  8. spawn_incident: "Atmospheric contamination" (major)

docs.title: Dramatic Arrival
docs.text:
"Distress Signal"

  1. emit_event: "Receiving transmission on emergency frequency"
  2. delay: 3s
  3. send_transmission: Garbled distress call
  4. spawn_task: "Clean up signal" (Operations, 20s)
  5. delay: 15s
  6. send_transmission: Clear distress message with coordinates
  7. spawn_incident: "Rescue operation" (moderate)

docs.title: Widgets
docs.text: Widgets are the building blocks of panels. Each widget type displays specific information or provides specific interactions.

docs.title: Widget Categories
docs.text:
Widgets are organized into four categories:

Category Purpose Layout Structure and spacing Display Show system status and data Interactive Player actions and live feeds Specialized Complex visualizations

docs.title: Layout Widgets
docs.text: Layout widgets help structure panels visually. They don't display ship data.

docs.title: Title
docs.text:
Panel title with optional subtitle. Use at the top of panels to identify the station or view.

  • Use for: Panel headers, section labels
  • Config: Title text, subtitle text

docs.title: Divider
docs.text:
Horizontal or vertical separator line. Creates visual breaks between widget groups.

  • Use for: Separating panel sections
  • Config: Orientation (horizontal/vertical)

docs.title: Spacer
docs.text:
Visible spacer with a subtle border. Reserves space and shows panel structure.

  • Use for: Creating gaps, placeholder areas
  • Config: None (size controlled by dimensions)

docs.title: Invisible Spacer
docs.text:
Completely invisible spacer. Creates gaps without any visual indication.

  • Use for: Fine-tuning layout, padding edges
  • Config: None

docs.title: Display Widgets
docs.text: Display widgets show system status and ship data.

docs.title: Status Display
docs.text:
Shows a single system's current status with color-coded indicator and label.

  • Use for: Quick status checks, dashboard overviews
  • Bindings: system_state_id - the system to display
  • Config: Orientation (horizontal/vertical), custom label

Status indicators use both color and shape:

  • Operational → green circle
  • Degraded → amber triangle
  • Compromised/Critical → orange/red diamond
  • Destroyed → deep red X
  • Offline → gray hollow circle

docs.title: Health Bar
docs.text:
Visual bar showing a system's current value as a percentage of capacity.

  • Use for: Reactor output, shield strength, fuel levels
  • Bindings: system_state_id - system with numeric value
  • Config: Custom label, show percentage

The bar color changes based on the value:

  • High values → green
  • Medium values → amber
  • Low values → red

docs.title: Asset Display
docs.text:
Individual weapon, drone, or probe with ammunition count and status.

  • Use for: Weapon loadouts, deployable assets
  • Bindings: system_state_id - the asset system
  • Config: Asset type, show ammo count

docs.title: System Dependencies
docs.text:
Graph visualization showing how systems depend on each other. When a parent system degrades, children are affected.

  • Use for: Engineering diagnostics, understanding cascade failures
  • Bindings: system_state_ids - systems to include in graph
  • Config: Layout direction, show status colors

docs.title: Data Table
docs.text:
Tabular display of structured data from a dataset.

  • Use for: Cargo manifests, crew rosters, mission logs
  • Bindings: dataset_id - the data source
  • Config: Columns to display, sorting

docs.title: Environment Summary
docs.text:
Atmospheric conditions, gravity, and habitat status at a glance.

  • Use for: Life support monitoring, EVA readiness
  • Bindings: system_state_ids - atmosphere, gravity, habitat systems
  • Config: Display format

docs.title: Interactive Widgets
docs.text: Interactive widgets allow player actions or show live updating feeds.

docs.title: Posture Display
docs.text:
Ship threat posture indicator with click-to-change controls (if permitted).

  • Use for: Bridge command decisions, Rules of Engagement
  • Bindings: Reads ship posture state
  • Config: Allow player changes, posture options

Posture levels typically include:

  • Condition Green - Peacetime
  • Condition Yellow - Elevated alert
  • Condition Red - Combat ready
  • Condition Black - Under attack

docs.title: Alert Feed
docs.text:
Scrolling list of recent alerts and ship events.

  • Use for: Situational awareness, event history
  • Bindings: None (reads ship events automatically)
  • Config: Max items, filter by severity

Alerts are color-coded by severity and show timestamps.

docs.title: Task Queue
docs.text:
List of active tasks assigned to the current station. Players can claim and complete tasks.

  • Use for: Crew coordination, responding to incidents
  • Bindings: None (filters by current station)
  • Config: Show completed tasks, task limit

Task workflow:

  1. Task appears in queue (pending)
  2. Player claims task (active)
  3. Player completes task (succeeded/failed)
  4. Timed tasks may expire

docs.title: Contact Tracker
docs.text:
Contact list with threat indicators. Players can pin contacts and expand dossiers.

  • Use for: Tactical awareness, identifying threats
  • Bindings: None (reads contacts automatically)
  • Config: Default sort, show dossiers

Contact information includes:

  • Designation and class
  • Threat level (friendly/neutral/hostile)
  • Distance and bearing
  • Dossier notes (expandable)

docs.title: Transmission Console
docs.text:
Incoming transmissions and messages displayed as they arrive.

  • Use for: Communications, narrative delivery
  • Bindings: None (reads transmissions automatically)
  • Config: Max messages, auto-scroll

Transmissions include sender, timestamp, and message content.

docs.title: Specialized Widgets
docs.text: Specialized widgets provide complex visualizations.

docs.title: Holomap
docs.text:
Interactive ship deck plan with real-time markers showing crew, damage, and points of interest.

  • Use for: Internal ship awareness, damage control coordination
  • Bindings: Configured per holomap
  • Config: Deck image, marker types, zoom level

docs.title: Ship Log
docs.text:
Timeline of all ship events with filtering and search capabilities.

  • Use for: Mission recap, investigating past events
  • Bindings: None (reads full event history)
  • Config: Default filters, time range

docs.title: Radar
docs.text:
Polar radar display showing sensor contacts with range rings and bearing indicators.

  • Use for: Tactical overview, spatial awareness
  • Bindings: None (reads contacts automatically)
  • Config: Range scale, contact icons, sweep animation

Radar features:

  • Contacts positioned by bearing and distance
  • Range rings for distance reference
  • Contact icons indicate type/threat
  • Optional sweep animation

docs.title: Mini-Game
docs.text:
Launcher for interactive mini-games tied to task completion.

  • Use for: Skill-based task resolution
  • Bindings: Task-specific
  • Config: Game type, difficulty

Mini-Games

Mini-game support is still being developed. Currently shows a placeholder.

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text:
Most widgets share these configuration options:

Option Description Custom Label Override the default widget title Position Grid X/Y coordinates Size Width/height in grid units

docs.title: Bindings
docs.text:
Bindings connect widgets to data:

system_state_id: "reactor-main"     // Single system
system_state_ids: ["power", "life"] // Multiple systems
dataset_id: "cargo-manifest"        // Tabular data

docs.title: Minimum Sizes
docs.text:
Each widget type has minimum dimensions to ensure readability:

Widget Min Width Min Height Status Display 1 1 Health Bar 1 1 Task Queue 2 1 Radar 4 4 Holomap 2 1

The panel editor enforces these minimums automatically.

docs.title: Status States
docs.text: Every system in Starship HUD uses a consistent status model. This page documents all status states, their visual representation, and behavior.

docs.title: Status Overview
docs.text: Status Color Icon Shape Motion Meaning Operational Green Circle Stable System functioning normally Degraded Amber/Yellow-Green Triangle Mild flicker Reduced capacity, attention needed Compromised Orange Diamond Intermittent glitch Significant issues, action required Critical Red Diamond Pulsing Imminent failure, immediate action Destroyed Deep Red X Inert Non-functional, cannot be repaired Offline Gray Hollow Circle None Intentionally disabled

docs.title: Color + Shape
docs.text:
Status is never communicated by color alone. Each status has a distinct icon shape as a fallback for colorblind users:

  • Circle = good (operational)
  • Triangle = warning (degraded)
  • Diamond = danger (compromised, critical)
  • X = dead (destroyed)
  • Hollow = inactive (offline)

docs.title: Motion Semantics
docs.text:
Animation reinforces status meaning:

  • Stable - No motion, steady state
  • Mild flicker - Occasional subtle flicker, something's not quite right
  • Intermittent glitch - More pronounced, irregular disruption
  • Pulsing - Rhythmic urgency, demands attention
  • Inert - No animation, system is dead

docs.title: Glow Effects
docs.text:
Status colors also affect ambient glow around widgets:

  • Operational: subtle cyan/green glow
  • Degraded: amber glow
  • Critical: red pulsing glow
  • Offline/Destroyed: no glow

docs.title: Normal Flow
docs.text:
operational ↔ degraded ↔ compromised ↔ critical → destroyed

Systems can move up or down in severity based on:

  • Damage events
  • Repair actions
  • Cascade effects from dependencies
  • Scenario actions

docs.title: Terminal State
docs.text: Destroyed is a terminal state. Once a system is destroyed, it cannot transition to any other state without GM override.

docs.title: Offline
docs.text:
Any non-destroyed system can be taken offline and brought back online:

operational → offline → operational
degraded → offline → degraded

Offline represents intentional deactivation, not damage.

docs.title: Alert Thresholds
docs.text:
Status affects how alerts are generated and displayed:

Status Alert Level Visibility Operational None - Degraded Info Station only Compromised Warning Station-level Critical Critical Ship-wide Destroyed Critical Ship-wide Offline Info Station only

docs.title: Status Display Widget
docs.text:
Shows the status directly with color, icon, and label:

┌─────────────────────┐
│ ● REACTOR           │  ← Green circle = operational
└─────────────────────┘

┌─────────────────────┐
│ ▲ REACTOR           │  ← Amber triangle = degraded
└─────────────────────┘

┌─────────────────────┐
│ ◆ REACTOR           │  ← Red diamond = critical
└─────────────────────┘

docs.title: Health Bar Widget
docs.text:
Color changes based on the underlying value:

  • 70-100%: Green
  • 40-69%: Amber
  • 0-39%: Red

The bar also reflects system status through border glow.

docs.title: System Dependencies Widget
docs.text: Shows status cascade - when a parent system degrades, children show their effective status accounting for the degradation.

docs.title: CSS Reference
docs.text:
For advanced customization, status colors are defined as CSS custom properties:

--status-operational: #3fb950;
--status-degraded: #d4a72c;
--status-compromised: #db6d28;
--status-critical: #f85149;
--status-destroyed: #8b0000;
--status-offline: #6e7681;

Status-specific CSS classes:

.status-operational { }
.status-degraded { }
.status-compromised { }
.status-critical { }
.status-destroyed { }
.status-offline { }

docs.title: For GMs
docs.text:
• Use the full range - Don't jump straight to critical; build tension through degraded → compromised
  • Combine status with narrative - A status change is more impactful with a transmission or event
  • Consider dependencies - Degrading a core system affects everything that depends on it

docs.title: For Panel Design
docs.text:
• Show key systems prominently - Critical systems deserve larger widgets
  • Group related systems - Engineering panel shows power systems together
  • Include a mix - Show both status indicators and health bars for important systems
